intro: Coptosperma somaliense, commonly known as the Somali tamarind, is a small evergreen tree native to the Horn of Africa. It belongs to the family Malvaceae and is characterized by its compound leaves and showy yellow flowers. The plant produces small, round fruits that contain a single seed surrounded by a fleshy, edible pulp. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, often found in dry woodlands and coastal areas. Due to its ornamental value and potential medicinal uses, it is of interest to botanists and horticulturists.
